articles.headline: A Hand Up for Students Facing a Mountain of Debt
articles.snippet: SafeStart aims to reduce the fear of debt that might keep 18-year-olds from borrowing for school in the first place.
articles.abstract: SafeStart aims to reduce the fear of debt that might keep 18-year-olds from borrowing for school in the first place.
articles.lead_paragraph: The biggest problem for consumers of American higher education is that many of them must take on a mountain of debt to get the degree they want. That intimidating quandary has inspired some unique, though often unsuccessful, attempts to make student loans more affordable over the years.

articles.headline: A Tale of Two Judges
articles.snippet: Federal judges rejected prearranged deals in the Bank of America/Merrill Lynch and Madoff cases. One was a good move, the other perhaps not.
articles.abstract: Federal judges rejected prearranged deals in the Bank of America/Merrill Lynch and Madoff cases. One was a good move, the other perhaps not.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jed S. Rakoff and Richard J. Sullivan, both judges on the Federal District Court, have courtrooms seven floors apart in the United States courthouse in Lower Manhattan. Judge Rakoff, appointed by Bill Clinton in 1996, is a veteran of the bench, with a well-earned reputation for being a jurist’s jurist. With his white beard, he looks a little like Santa Claus, only more distinguished. He is 66 years old.

articles.headline: At Sinclair Community College, Focus Is Jobs
articles.snippet: Autoworkers, seeing no future in the industry, have turned to a model community college in Ohio to acquire marketable skills in other fields.
articles.abstract: Autoworkers, seeing no future in the industry, have turned to a model community college in Ohio to acquire marketable skills in other fields.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio  When Todd Sollar was laid off after 11 years at General Motors, he enrolled at Sinclair Community College in downtown Dayton to study robotics.

articles.headline: Nortel Sale to Ericsson Stirs Protest in Canada
articles.snippet: The sale of research and patents to Ericsson of Sweden could endanger Canada’s national security, opponents of the deal argue.
articles.abstract: The sale of research and patents to Ericsson of Sweden could endanger Canada’s national security, opponents of the deal argue.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA  At the start of this decade, Nortel Networks was perhaps the most hated company in Canada. The collapse of technology stocks combined with an accounting scandal destroyed the widely held telecommunications company’s share price and, with that, the savings of thousands of Canadians.

articles.headline: BB&T Takes Over Failing Colonial BancGroup
articles.snippet: The takeover agreement marks the largest bank failure of 2009 and could be the most costly since the sudden failure of IndyMac Bancorp last year.
articles.abstract: The takeover agreement marks the largest bank failure of 2009 and could be the most costly since the sudden failure of IndyMac Bancorp last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s biggest banks may be roaring back to life, but trouble still lurks in corners of the financial industry that remain plagued by a legacy of bad investments.

articles.headline: Idle Iraqi Date Farms Show Decline of Economy
articles.snippet: A nation that once had a robust farming sector is becoming dependent on imports and oil to sustain itself.
articles.abstract: A nation that once had a robust farming sector is becoming dependent on imports and oil to sustain itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Late July and early August is date harvesting season in Iraq, when within the span of a few weeks the desert sun turns hard green spheres into tender, golden brown fruit prized for its sweetness.

articles.headline: Retailers See Back-to-School Sales Slowing
articles.snippet: Halfway through the back-to-school shopping season, predictions of the worst performance for stores in more than a decade are yet another sign that consumers are clinging to every dollar.
articles.abstract: Halfway through the back-to-school shopping season, predictions of the worst performance for stores in more than a decade are yet another sign that consumers are clinging to every dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: Halfway through the back-to-school shopping season, retail professionals are predicting the worst performance for stores in more than a decade, yet another sign that consumers are clinging to every dollar.

articles.headline: U.S. Weighs Action Over Citi’s $100 Million Man
articles.snippet: Citigroup says the federal government cannot review the compensation packages for two traders — one earning $98 million and another $30 million.
articles.abstract: Citigroup says the federal government cannot review the compensation packages for two traders — one earning $98 million and another $30 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senior Obama administration officials were wrestling on Friday with how to handle an explosive executive pay issue involving two traders’ compensation package of nearly $130 million that Citigroup says is exempt from government review.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Eric Dash

articles.headline: 2 Killings Stoke Kashmiri Rage at Indian Force
articles.snippet: In Kashmir, the rapes and killings of two young women near the camps of Indian security forces have focused attention on their continuing presence.
articles.abstract: In Kashmir, the rapes and killings of two young women near the camps of Indian security forces have focused attention on their continuing presence.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHOPIAN, Kashmir  On a sunny late spring afternoon, Asiya and Nilofar Jan left home to tend to their family’s apple orchard. Along the way they passed a gantlet of police camps wreathed in razor wire as they crossed the bridge over the ankle-deep Rambi River.

articles.headline: Believers Invest in the Gospel of Getting Rich
articles.snippet: Even in a downturn, preachers in the “prosperity gospel” movement are drawing sizable, adoring audiences.
articles.abstract: Even in a downturn, preachers in the “prosperity gospel” movement are drawing sizable, adoring audiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH  Onstage before thousands of believers weighed down by debt and economic insecurity, Kenneth and Gloria Copeland and their all-star lineup of “prosperity gospel” preachers delighted the crowd with anecdotes about the luxurious lives they had attained by following the Word of God.

articles.headline: Emanuel Wields Power Freely, and Faces the Risks
articles.snippet: Rahm Emanuel is emerging as possibly the most influential White House chief of staff in a generation.
articles.abstract: Rahm Emanuel is emerging as possibly the most influential White House chief of staff in a generation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As White House chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel was the one to bring the hammer down on Sidney Blumenthal.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Weinsteins Struggle to Regain Their Touch
articles.snippet: Four years after Disney bought the Weinsteins out of Miramax, the brothers are under serious stress.
articles.abstract: Four years after Disney bought the Weinsteins out of Miramax, the brothers are under serious stress.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the wee hours of Friday morning, Quentin Tarantino stood in a West Village bar that had opened for him and his entourage  cast members of his new movie, “Inglourious Basterds,” and his longtime producers, Bob and Harvey Weinstein. Swinging a blue cocktail in one hand, he held forth about the time that Harvey told him he’d like to invest in a restaurant.

articles.headline: The Quick Buck Just Got Quicker
articles.snippet: A study finds that short-term incentive pay has become a bigger part of the compensation pie.
articles.abstract: A study finds that short-term incentive pay has become a bigger part of the compensation pie.
articles.lead_paragraph: WITH outsized and corrupting corporate pay packages under scrutiny, you might think that companies would be rushing to tamp down their compensation plans. Making sure that pay actually rewards long-term performance, for example, seems a fairly obvious way to allay shareholder fears that managers are lining their pockets rather than safeguarding their companies.

articles.headline: G.I. Jane Breaks the Combat Barrier
articles.snippet: Before 2001, America’s military women had rarely seen ground combat. Afghanistan and Iraq have changed that.
articles.abstract: Before 2001, America’s military women had rarely seen ground combat. Afghanistan and Iraq have changed that.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the convoy rumbled up the road in Iraq, Specialist Veronica Alfaro was struck by the beauty of fireflies dancing in the night. Then she heard the unmistakable pinging of tracer rounds and, in a Baghdad moment, realized the insects were illuminated bullets.

articles.headline: Bolt Shatters 100-Meter World Record
articles.snippet: The Jamaican sprinting sensation Usain Bolt became the first person to run under 9.6 seconds at track’s world championship in Berlin.
articles.abstract: The Jamaican sprinting sensation Usain Bolt became the first person to run under 9.6 seconds at track’s world championship in Berlin.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN  All those curious to know just how fast Usain Bolt might have gone if he had not stopped sprinting near the end of his world-record run at the Olympics last year now have a clearer answer.

articles.headline: Threats by Taliban May Sway Vote in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The insurgents’ campaign against this week’s election may cost President Hamid Karzai vital support from his fellow Pashtuns.
articles.abstract: The insurgents’ campaign against this week’s election may cost President Hamid Karzai vital support from his fellow Pashtuns.
articles.lead_paragraph: TARAKAI, Afghanistan  A group of Taliban fighters made their announcement in the bazaar of a nearby village a few days ago, and the word spread fast: anyone caught voting in the presidential election will have his finger  the one inked for the ballot  cut off.

articles.headline: Fox Business Needs a Lift. Could It Be Don Imus?
articles.snippet: The Fox Business Network may be taking a page from its sibling, Fox News: hire radio personalities.
articles.abstract: The Fox Business Network may be taking a page from its sibling, Fox News: hire radio personalities.
articles.lead_paragraph: The News Corporation needs television viewers to find the Fox Business Network, and it thinks the cowboy-hat-wearing radio host Don Imus could help.

articles.headline: Sites Ask Users to Spend to Save
articles.snippet: Swoopo.com sells a variety of products in auctions that typically top out at a small fraction of the retail price, but charges a fee for each bid.
articles.abstract: Swoopo.com sells a variety of products in auctions that typically top out at a small fraction of the retail price, but charges a fee for each bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some people will stop at nothing to snap up a bargain  even if it means paying too much.

articles.headline: The Paper That Doesn’t Want to Be Free
articles.snippet: With few signs that advertising is rebounding, other publishers are moving to imitate The Financial Times by erecting so-called pay walls for online content.
articles.abstract: With few signs that advertising is rebounding, other publishers are moving to imitate The Financial Times by erecting so-called pay walls for online content.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, when other media executives were convinced that the only way to succeed on the Web was to give away their content, The Financial Times played the eccentric.

articles.headline: AOL Blossoms as Print Retreats
articles.snippet: Its 300 producers in New York are backed by hundreds of freelancers and programmers across the globe who churn out copy and edit photos.
articles.abstract: Its 300 producers in New York are backed by hundreds of freelancers and programmers across the globe who churn out copy and edit photos.
articles.lead_paragraph: The office at Ninth Street and Broadway in Manhattan in the former Wanamaker’s department store has all of the trademarks of a well-financed digital start-up. Young people eat pizza and chat about applications while others are jammed into conference rooms discussing search optimization. The only oddity in the futuristic tableau comes when you step off the elevator to see three large letters: A O L.

articles.headline: Japan’s Economy Shows Signs of Improvement
articles.snippet: A modest 0.9 percent expansion, which met expectations, may come to mark Japan’s emergence from recession.
articles.abstract: A modest 0.9 percent expansion, which met expectations, may come to mark Japan’s emergence from recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Japan’s economy rebounded in the latest quarter for the first time in a year, signaling the possible end of the country’s deepest recession since World War II and brightening prospects for a widespread global recovery.

articles.headline: Living and Fighting Alongside Men, and Fitting In
articles.snippet: American military women have changed the way the U.S. goes to war — without the disruption of discipline and unit cohesion that some feared.
articles.abstract: American military women have changed the way the U.S. goes to war — without the disruption of discipline and unit cohesion that some feared.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORWARD OPERATING BASE WARHORSE, Iraq  There is no mistaking that this dusty, gravel-strewn camp northeast of Baghdad is anything other than a combat outpost in a still-hostile land. And there is no mistaking that women in uniform have had a transformative effect on it.

articles.headline: Job Search Firms: Big Pitches and Fees, Few Jobs
articles.snippet: A bewildering, largely unregulated array of businesses offering assistance are leaving job seekers vulnerable.
articles.abstract: A bewildering, largely unregulated array of businesses offering assistance are leaving job seekers vulnerable.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAPERVILLE, Ill.  In retrospect, Kerry Fischman said he should have paid more attention to the nagging concern he felt when the saleswoman from the job search company kept pressing him to sign the contract and send in his credit card number.

articles.headline: Pessimism Still Grips Wall Street
articles.snippet: Analysts said the sell-off was in part a reaction to weak consumer confidence numbers released in the U.S.
articles.abstract: Analysts said the sell-off was in part a reaction to weak consumer confidence numbers released in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, it seemed as if nothing could hold back investors trying to will a recovery into reality. Stocks gained week after week, adding up to a 42 percent rise since mid-March, despite troubling news of bank loan defaults, mixed corporate earnings reports and lukewarm forecasts from Federal Reserve Bank officials.
